newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: INTERVIEW-MICROSOFT SAYS APPLE TIE-UP NOT HOSTILE.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-MICROSOFT SAYS APPLE TIE-UP NOT HOSTILE.

text.p: U.S. software giant Microsoft Corp said on Wednesday its US$150 million investment in troubled Apple Computer Inc was not a hostile move.
"Absolutely not," Natasha Kwan, Microsoft Singapore's marketing manager told Reuters when asked if the tie-up was a hostile move or aimed at a takeover of Apple.
Officials also said there were no current plans to use Apple's technology on Microsoft's platform.
"This whole alliance, there's nothing covered on the operating system. It's about us developing applications for their platform. There's no mention of such an arrangement," Kwan said.
On Lee, group program manager of the desktop & business systems division, conceded that while there were no current plans to use Apple's technology, Microsoft could do so in future.
As part of the deal, the two companies signed a broad patent cross licensing agreement. Lee said Microsoft could use the patents to Apple's core technology for improvisation later on.
Analysts have said Microsoft could be eyeing Apple's software technology, including its multimedia capabilities.
"At this point we will be glad to execute what we have announced already," Lee said.
Under the deal, Microsoft has promised to develop major product upgrades for Apple's MacIntosh operating system for a period of five years, including its Office software for the Mac 1998 version.
Microsoft's Internet Explorer will become Apple's default Web browser but does not exclude use of Netscape Communications Corp's products.
Kwan said Microsoft was more interested in protecting its own customers who use Apple's machines.
Microsoft has a worldwide installed base of eight million Office suite users on the Mac platform, Kwan said.
She said Microsoft's investment would ensure Apple's survival and pave the way for more software sales for Microsoft.
"Mac users have to get out of the notion that for Apple to be successful, Microsoft has to fail. In the internet alone, we can't work alone, even Microsoft," she said.
